title: Expenses and benefits: computers loaned to an employee

details.description: Tax and reporting rules for employers loaning computers to employees
details.alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for employees' computers

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
As an employer loaning computers to your employees, you have certain National Insurance and reporting obligations.

If you loaned a computer to an employee before 6 April 2006 and this arrangement is still in place, different rules may apply - read technical guidance from HMRC.

parts.title: What's exempt
parts.body:
You don’t have to report or pay anything to HMRC if either of the following apply:

  • the employee earns at a rate of less than £8,500 a year
  • the computer is provided for work purposes and the employee doesn’t make ‘significant’ private use of it

parts.title: What to report and pay
parts.body:
If the computers you loan to employees aren’t exempt, you must report them to HMRC and pay National Insurance.

Computers available for private use

For employees earning at a rate of £8,500 or more a year, or directors:

  • report on form P11D, section L
  • pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit

parts.title: Work out the value
parts.body:
If you need to report or pay National Insurance on the benefit, work out the value by following these steps:

  1. Calculate 20% of the greater of either the computer’s market value at the time you provided it, or any rental charge you pay for it.

  2. Add any running costs that you cover.

  3. Take away any amount that your employee contributes to cost of the loan.

parts.title: Technical guidance
parts.body:
The following guides contain more detailed information:

  • the meaning of ‘not significant use for private purposes’

  • cash equivalent of assets placed at the disposal of a director or employee

  • computers - partial exemption abolished 2006/07
